text: hello in this video I will be showing
you how AWS firewall manager can now
manage the Palo Alto Network's Next
Generation firewall service
this new capability will enable you to
centrally deploy and monitor the cloud
Next Generation firewalls or ngfws
across all AWS virtual private clouds or
vpcs in your organization
this is important because it allows you
to have a single firewall management
solution to deploy and gives you the
ability to manage both AWS native
firewalls and Palo Alto Network's cloud
and gfws side by side
here are the benefits and features that
will be demonstrated later in the video
the first is that with centralized
management through firewall manager you
will have visibility into non-compliant
configurations across accounts in your
organization
the second is that any new or existing
ngfw configurations can now be set up to
follow your workloads
this ensures that the policy you define
for your ngfw deployment can
automatically be added to new accounts
in vpcs
lastly with firewall manager as the
orchestrator you are given the option to
deploy the ngfw service as a centralized
or distributed deployment
in these deployment models you can
decide whether you would like a central
point of inspection for your vpcs
through a centrally shared inspection
VPC or you can choose to deploy a
central policy for your cloud and gfw
and perform local inspection for all of
the in-scope vpcs
the rule stacks for these policies and
deployment models are both configured on
the Palo Alto Cloud ngfw portal
here are the links where you can learn
more about the services and
configurations I just discussed
now I would like to show you the process
of adding the cloud ngfw to your AWS
firewall manager assuming you have
already set up AWS firewall manager The
Next Step you will need is a
subscription to the Palo Alto networks
cloud in gfw
this can be located by searching in the
search bar for the product and clicking
Marketplace on the left hand side to
view the offering
once you've clicked into the service you
will have an option to subscribe
once you hit subscribe you will be
redirected to Palo alto's website to set
up an account and instantiate the
service
in a few minutes you'll receive an
activation email and you will see the
cloud in gfw offering available to you
in your AWS portal
to manage the service with firewall
manager click firewall manager and then
click settings and scroll down
here you will see a third-party firewall
Association status section
if your Cloud ngfw offering was
associated with the same account as AWS
firewall manager you will see your
service listed in this section with a
status of unassociated and a
subscription of active
in order to manage the cloud in gfw
Click the service in the list and then
click associate
if you have issues with getting the
cloud in gfw to appear in this section
it is likely that there is still an
account related setup needed from the
Palo Alto Inn the main configuration to
check would be the AWS accounts
associated with the cloud in gfw from
the ngfw cloud portal as shown here
please note that when adding this
account the Palo Alto network service
will request cross account access
the cloud formation template to do this
is available in your Palo Alto cloud in
gfw Portal and is also available on the
policy scope page
after associating the cloud in gfw with
firewall manager you will be able to
create policies specifically for the
cloud in gfw
after clicking create policy you will
see the new options to select the cloud
in gfw and the deployment model you
would like to apply for this policy
on the next page you can start to define
the policy adding in your wool stacks
and logging options
the rules tax configuration is done on
the Palo Alto portal and synced with AWS
firewall manager so that they can be
viewed and selected here
you are also given the option of logging
the different types of logs available
from the ngfw to AWS services like S3
cloudtrail or Kinesis fire hose
this next page I am showing covers the
policy scope where you can configure
what accounts and resources the ngfw
endpoints will actually protect
on the last two pages you have the
option to create tags for distribution
to vpcs and an option to review the
configuration before deployment
I hope that what I have just shown you
can be of use when you decide to use AWS
firewall manager to configure your Palo
Alto networks cloud in gfw thank you
